There seems to be a bit of confusion in the Q1 (4:40): YES, we can measure a frequency of a purely classical harmonic oscillator better than the uncertainty suggests (if we have good SNR). But, NO, the uncertainty doesn't hold for purely classical system (cause we can measure frequency more precisely).

That is a sine wave in infinite time. But you make measurements for a finite time  Δt in real life. So if you take the Fourier Transform of a function that is a sine wave only for interval Δt and zero elsewhere and plot its frequency spectrum, you will find that it is not exactly δ(ω-ω0) but has a finite peak at ω0 and width Δω0.

I think he was talking about saturating the excited state in a 2 level system. Similarly, saturation in quantum optics may be saturation of a mode

In two level system, you cannot excite more than half of atoms to the excited state. Therefore, if you have half of atoms in the excited state, you saturate the 2-level system. In harmonic oscillator, before you excite half of the atoms to the first excited state (lowest excited state), atoms in the first excited state transfer to the second excited state.. If you have atoms in the second excited state, you are in three level system (ground, first excited, and second excited state).
